sub_topic: Length contraction in a moving frame of reference
message_1: What would be the measured length of a 3-meter-long object moving at a velocity of 0.8c relative to an observer at rest? Use the formula for length contraction in a moving frame of reference to calculate your answer.
message_2:
To calculate the length contraction of an object moving at a high velocity relative to an observer, we use the Lorentz contraction formula:

L = L0 * sqrt(1 - v^2/c^2)

where L is the contracted length, L0 is the proper length (length at rest), v is the relative velocity, and c is the speed of light.

In this case, L0 = 3 meters and v = 0.8c.

L = 3 * sqrt(1 - (0.8c)^2/c^2)

L = 3 * sqrt(1 - 0.64)

L = 3 * sqrt(0.36)

L = 3 * 0.6

L = 1.8 meters

The measured length of the 3-meter-long object moving at a velocity of 0.8c relative to an observer at rest would be 1.8 meters.
